notes: Interesting cyclic nature of numbers when powers of 3 are removed.
source: 2007 MOSP Tests Edited By Zuming Feng, Practice Test 8, Problem 1
stnl: Let p be a prime greater than 3. Prove that there exist integers a1, a2, ... , an with -p/2 < a1 < a2 < ... < an < p/2 such that (p-a1)(p-a2)...(p-an) / |a1 a2 ... an| is a perfect power of 3.
stwl:
Let $p$ be a prime greater than $3$. Prove that there exist integers $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ with
\[-\frac{p}{2} < a_1 < a_2 < \cdots < a_n < \frac{p}{2}\]
such that 
\[\frac{(p-a_1)(p-a_2)\cdots (p-a_n)}{|a_1 a_2 \cdots a_n|}\]
is a perfect power of $3$.
